entry.title: Are blockchains the right choice for global data infrastructure?
Data infrastructure technology: are blockchains the answer?
entry.summary: How do we make sure data infrastructure is always available, and always trustworthy? Are blockchains the answer?

entry.title: The Ghost of Open Data Future
entry.summary: This is a transcript of my part of the ODI Friday Lunchtime Lecture on 19th December, titled ["A Christmas Carol - The ghosts of open data’s past, present and future"](http://theodi.org/lunchtime-lectures/friday-lunchtime-lecture-a-christmas-carol-the-ghosts-of-open-datas-past-present-and-future)

entry.title: Thinking without data portals: searchable data
entry.summary: Ah, the mid-nineties; good times. Personally, I spent them drinking in student bars, listening to [BritPop](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XV8CxSO5imQ), and exploring the early web as it grew from just a few sites into something that would change the world.

entry.title: OKFestival 2014: Ich bin eine Currywurst
entry.summary: I spent last week in Berlin at the 2014 [Open Knowledge Festival](http://2014.okfestival.org/), along with a good number of other ODI staff.

entry.title: Discussing Digital Democracy
entry.summary: Today I was lucky enough to visit the Houses of Parliament and take part in a roundtable discussion as part of the [Speaker's Commission on Digital Democracy](http://www.parliament.uk/business/commons/the-speaker/speakers-commission-on-digital-democracy/). The commission is looking at all aspects of how democracy can be enhanced in the digital age, and will be reporting early next year.

entry.title: CSVHub - GitHub diffs for CSV files
Introducing Philbot - a DIY storage appliance
entry.summary: Here at the ODI, we love creating content. [Phil](http://theodi.org/team/phil-lang), our Digital Production Editor, handles loads of video, audio, photography, and so on, and because a lot of it is rather large, his laptop threatens to bust its seams on a regular basis. So, he walked over and asked if there was anything the [tech team](https://twitter.com/ukoditech) knew of that would give him more space to work with.

entry.title: Tech Team Week Notes #44
entry.summary: For the ODI tech team, last week was "20% week". This is when we have time to ourselves to spend on innovation projects, learning, and so on. When we started, we tried to do a Google-style one-day-a-week rhythm for this time, but found rapidly that it was getting squeezed. Having one week in every five blocked out is a much more successful way of allocating the time, for us.

entry.title: Adapting Git for simple data
entry.summary: A while ago I wrote about using [Git for data publishing](http://theodi.org/blog/git-data-publishing), and talked about how the tools and particularly the workflow� used by many open source projects could revolutionise how we create, publish, and collaborate on open data. I'm not the only one thinking this, of course; amongst many others, �Rufus Pollock from the OKFN has [written on the same subject](http://blog.okfn.org/2013/07/02/git-and-github-for-data/)� [many times](http://blog.okfn.org/2010/07/12/we-need-distributed-revisionversion-control-for-data/), and they've been hosting [datasets on Github](https://github.com/datasets)�for a good while now, as have other organisations.

entry.title: Tech Team Week Notes #39
entry.summary: ![Penguin James](http://bd7a65e2cb448908f934-86a50c88e47af9e1fb58ce0672b5a500.r32.cf3.rackcdn.com/uploads/assets/legacy/penguin.jpg)Last week started with a change of scenery, as the ODI decamped to [Great Brampton House](https://twitter.com/GreatBrampton) in Herefordshire, for two days of intensive strategic planning. During the quieter periods, [Tom](http://www.theodi.org/people/tom-heath) and [Ulrich](http://www.theodi.org/people/ulrich-atz) mastered the finer points of�croquet, while the rest of us practised our Gin & Tonic technique.�Having then laid out our plans for our next three months, we then returned to London to catch up on all the work we missed while we were away.

entry.title: Tech Team Week Notes #34
entry.summary: Last week was fairly quiet, with [Stuart](http://theodi.org/people/stuart-harrison) off on holiday, no doubt swanning around full of the joys of spring.

entry.title: Git for Data Publishing
entry.summary: Over the last few years, open source software development�has been revolutionised by the adoption of distributed version control systems. Using tools like [git](http://git-scm.com) and particularly sites like [GitHub](http://github.com), it's now incredibly easy to contribute to a project. This has lowered the bar for�participation, and has had an incredible impact on the quality and range of open source output, and enabled fantastic service ecosystems and business models to build up.

entry.title: Tech Team Week Notes #23
entry.summary: It's ODI week 23, and in tech land it's the first week of Sprint 3. Time is going very fast!

entry.title: Open Workflows for Open Teams (and closed ones too)
entry.summary: It's been six weeks since I joined the ODI, and so far, the most interesting thing about working here�has been the approach we take to software development. [As others have mentioned](http://theodi.org/blog/better-living-through-openness), we are trying to be radically open in how we work, but I thought I'd go into a little more detail on our actual workflow. We're only two sprints in, so we're still iterating this�but it's working nicely so far.

entry.title: Tech Team Week Notes #18
entry.summary: In ODI time, last week was week 18, and the tech team were settled in and starting to put tools and systems in place.
